title: Does your handwriting change when you use a different pen? - Quora

response.answer_text: Aurora Diamante with 2,000+ diamonds set in case. Yes, it can. The more comfortable the pen feels in your hand, or wherever you hold it, the more likely the script is to signal reliably personality indications. There a many factors that determine how good a stylus feels: weight. width. ink. nib size, texture of case, kind of surface, sticker price, and more. Test out enough writing instruments to be sure which pleases you the most, for what particular writing job. If you can’t afford an Aurora or two, Pilot makes a very good pen for less than $20. And then there are peacock quill pens for kicks.

It might, but your handwriting literally comes out of all of your previous writing experience. So you have to factor that into your effort. Pens have their own physical output capability. I have been practicing calligraphy on a small level for years. so now, even with a ballpoint or rollerball, I can get some line variation out of the monoline pen. It looks surprisingly good. It is the person more than the pen that dictates the result.

Yes. I write sometimes in something looking like English and often it look like Sanskrit. I don't know Sanskrit. I rarely write by hand. I type a lot. And even when I was in school 20 odd years ago. Worse now. So when I get a pen that get my scribble to a readable level, I make a note. An hunt for them. :)
